intro_paragraph: This tool helps to determine if Section 899 might apply to your situation based on a series of questions. Follow the flowchart below to assess potential impact.

examples_content.title: Worked Example 1: Canadian SaaS Parent, US Sub, and Canada’s DST (Now in Effect)
examples_content.text:
Scenario A Canadian publicly traded SaaS company (“MapleCloud Inc.”) owns 100% of a US operating subsidiary (“MapleCloud USA”). The parent developed the proprietary software, which it licenses to MapleCloud USA for resale to US business customers. MapleCloud USA pays an annual royalty of $5 million to the Canadian parent for the right to market and distribute the software in the US. Canada enacts its Digital Services Tax (DST) effective January 1, 2026. The US Treasury lists Canada as a Discriminatory Foreign Country (DFC) under Section 899, effective the same date. Key Inputs
  • US Sub’s Outbound Royalty to Canada: $5,000,000/year
  • Standard US–Canada Income Tax Treaty Royalty Withholding: 0% (Article XII(2) – most royalties are exempt from US WHT under this treaty for unrelated-party arrangements, unless for use of patents, trademarks, etc.; for most software, 0% if not “copyrighted article”)
  • Section 899 Surcharge:
    • Year 1 (2026): +5% (so WHT becomes 5%)
    • Year 2 (2027): +10% (so WHT becomes 10%)
    • … (up to statutory 30% + 20% cap, but for most software royalties the practical maximum under §899 is 20%, since 30% statutory rate only applies to certain IP)
Step-by-Step Calculation Year 1 (2026): Pre-Section 899: $0 US withholding (treaty rate applies) With Section 899:
  • $250,000 US withholding ($5,000,000 * 5%)
  • Extra annual cost: $250,000 (previously zero)
Year 2 (2027): With Section 899:
  • $500,000 withheld ($5,000,000 * 10%)
Year 5 (2030), with +20% cap: With Section 899:
  • $1,000,000 withheld ($5,000,000 * 20%) (new max under §899)
Summary Table
YearWHT Rate (Treaty)WHT Rate (Section 899)Withholding TaxExtra Cost
Pre-20260%0%$0$0
20260%5%$250,000$250,000
20270%10%$500,000$500,000
2030+0%20% (cap)$1,000,000$1,000,000
Takeaways & Practical Notes
  • Dramatic Swing: The presence of Canada’s DST erases the traditional treaty protection (0% royalty WHT) that US–Canada SaaS models have relied on for decades, making US-to-Canada software/royalty flows far more expensive.
  • Escalating Pain: The effect is modest in year one but grows rapidly (5% increments) until the cap, introducing urgency for business planning.
  • Applicability: This scenario hits any Canadian SaaS company where the US sub licenses the IP and routes significant royalties back to Canada; substance in the US doesn’t change the exposure unless public company carveouts/regulation changes apply.
  • No US Corporate Tax Rate Change: For a US sub paying royalties, Section 899 affects only the WHT on outbound payments (unless other applicable person tests or BEAT triggers are also present).
  • Annual Stakeholder Risk: Canadian HQ, investors, and tax planners will have to monitor US compliance, manage forecasts, and may seek to restructure flows, e.g., via non-royalty service arrangements if possible.
Narrative Executive Summary If Canada enacts a DST, US subsidiaries of Canadian SaaS companies face a sudden and growing US withholding tax on royalty payments—even where the US–Canada treaty previously protected these flows. In Year 1 alone, a typical $5 million royalty payment would incur an unexpected US tax of $250,000; by Year 5, the cost rises to $1 million each year, underlining how Section 899 fundamentally reshapes cross-border SaaS economics between Canada and the US.

examples_content.title: Worked Example 2: Extraterritorial Tax Failing Carve-Outs
examples_content.text:
Scenario Acme US, a US-based e-commerce company, owns 100% of Acme Spain, its foreign subsidiary. Spain enacts a new “Significant Global Revenues Tax” on all digital platform operators that reach worldwide revenue thresholds, not just revenue earned in Spain. The US Treasury determines this Spanish tax is an “extraterritorial tax” (per Section 899(c)(2)) and lists Spain as a Discriminatory Foreign Country (DFC) as of January 1, 2026. Acme US is not a CFC (it is US-incorporated and owned), and no public company/widely held exemption applies (it is privately held). Acme Spain receives a $15 million intercompany interest payment from Acme US each year under a group financing arrangement. No safe harbor applies:
  • The Spanish tax is not an ordinary income tax, not VAT, not limited to Spanish-source income—so carve-outs for “generally applicable taxes” do NOT help.
  • The payments are between related parties; neither is >50% owned by US persons in a way that would create a controlling CFC shield.
Key Inputs
  • Interest payment from Acme US to Acme Spain: $15,000,000 per year
  • Standard US–Spain Income Tax Treaty WHT on interest: 10%
  • Section 899 surcharge schedule begins January 1, 2026:
    • Year 1: +5% = 15% total
    • Year 2: +10% = 20% total
    • Year 3: +15% = 25% total
    • Year 4: +20% = 30% (capped at US statutory rate if statutory rate is 30% for interest—here, yes)
Step-by-Step Calculation Year 1 (2026): Pre-Section 899:
  • $1,500,000 US withholding (treaty-protected) ($15,000,000 * 10%)
With Section 899:
  • $2,250,000 US withholding ($15,000,000 * 15%)
  • Extra cost: $750,000
Year 4 (2029, cap reached): With Section 899:
  • $4,500,000 US withholding (statutory cap) ($15,000,000 * 30%)
  • Extra cost versus before: $3,000,000
Summary Table
YearWHT Rate (Treaty)WHT under §899Withholding TaxExtra Cost
Pre-202610%10%$1,500,000$0
202610%15%$2,250,000$750,000
202710%20%$3,000,000$1,500,000
2029+10%30% (cap)$4,500,000$3,000,000
Key Points
  • No Carve-Outs: The Spanish global revenues tax sweeps in Acme US for worldwide profits, and doesn’t qualify as a “generally applicable” carve-out—thus, Section 899 is triggered.
  • No CFC/Widely Held/Public Company Relief: The payment is from US to foreign sub, but is still “caught” because the recipient is a DFC-resident corporation and doesn’t meet the US-owned CFC or public company exceptions.
  • Rapid Cost Escalation: The annual cost of cross-border group financing soars: after four years, Acme’s US–Spain interest flows face triple the tax cost incurred pre-899.
  • Multinational Structuring Implications: Existing group funding structures, tax-efficient cash pools, or IP holding arrangements with “problematic” countries can become prohibitively expensive—and operationally unviable—if the target country enacts currently disfavored “extraterritorial” taxes.
Executive Narrative Section 899 means that if a country like Spain imposes a digital or extraterritorial tax that sweeps up US businesses, any US group with financial ties to that country loses treaty protection on key payments—watching withholding rates escalate rapidly, and with no shield if they’re not a CFC or public entity. Just four years after Spain is blacklisted, a $15 million/year intra-group interest payment faces $4.5 million in US tax, three times the “normal” rate.

examples_content.title: Worked Example 3: UTPR Impact under BEAT Overlay
examples_content.text: This example will explore a hypothetical Undertaxed Profits Rule (UTPR) scenario where the §899 provisions interact with or modify the Base Erosion and Anti-abuse Tax (BEAT) for a U.S. corporation. (Detailed scenario, inputs, and step-by-step calculation will be presented here.)
